title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas
text: Protected Planet provides comprehensive data conservation areas worldwide. Specifically, provides World Database Protected Areas (WDPA) World Database Effective Area-Based Conservation Measures (WDOECM). databases used monitor performance existing protected areas, identify priority areas future conservation efforts. Additionally, databases receive monthly updates government agencies non-governmental organizations. However, associated several issues need addressed prior analysis dynamic nature databases means entire data cleaning process needs repeated obtaining new version. wdpar R package provides interface data available Protected Planet. Specifically, can used automatically obtain data World Database Protected Areas (WDPA) World Database Effective Area-Based Conservation Measures (WDOECM). also provides methods cleaning data databases following best practices (outlined Butchart et al. 2015; Protected Planet 2021; Runge et al. 2015). vignette, provide tutorial recommendations using package.

title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas
text: provide short introduction wdpar R package. First, load wdpar R package. also load dplyr ggmap R packages help explore data. Now download protected area data Malta Protected Planet. can achieve specifying Malta’s country name (.e. "Malta") Malta’s ISO3 code (.e. "MLT"). Since data downloaded temporary directory default, specify data downloaded persistent directory. means R won’t re-download dataset every time restart R session, R can simply re-load previously downloaded datasets needed. Next, clean data set. Briefly, cleaning steps include: excluding protected areas yet implemented, excluding protected areas limited conservation value, replacing missing data codes (e.g. "0") missing data values (.e. NA), replacing protected areas represented points circular protected areas correspond reported extent, repairing topological issues geometries, erasing overlapping areas. Please note , default, spatial data processing performed scale suitable national scale analyses (see recommendations local scale analyses). information data cleaning procedures, see wdpa_clean(). cleaning data set, perform additional step involves clipping terrestrial protected areas Malta’s coastline. Ideally, also clip marine protected areas Malta’s Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) data easy obtain per country basis (see https://www.marineregions.org/eez.php)). Now finished cleaning data, let’s preview data. information columns mean, please refer official manual (available English, French, Spanish, Russian). now reproject data longitude/latitude coordinates (EPSG:4326) visualization purposes. Next, can plot map showing boundaries Malta’s protected area system.  can also create histogram showing year protected area established.  Now let’s calculate statistics. can calculate total amount land ocean inside Malta’s protected area system (km2). can also calculate percentage land inside protected area system managed different categories (.e. using protected area management categories defined International Union Conservation Nature). can also plot map showing Malta’s protected areas color area according ’s management category.
code: # load packages library(wdpar) library(dplyr) library(ggmap) # download protected area data for Malta # (excluding areas represented as point localities) mlt_raw_pa_data <- wdpa_fetch(   "Malta", wait = TRUE, download_dir = rappdirs::user_data_dir("wdpar") ) # clean Malta data mlt_pa_data <- wdpa_clean(mlt_raw_pa_data) # download Malta boundary from Global Administrative Areas dataset file_path <- tempfile(fileext = ".gpkg") download.file(   "https://geodata.ucdavis.edu/gadm/gadm4.1/gpkg/gadm41_MLT.gpkg",   file_path )  # import Malta's boundary mlt_boundary_data <- sf::read_sf(file_path, "ADM_ADM_0")  # repair any geometry issues, dissolve the border, reproject to same # coordinate system as the protected area data, and repair the geometry again mlt_boundary_data <-   mlt_boundary_data %>%   st_set_precision(1000) %>%   sf::st_make_valid() %>%   st_set_precision(1000) %>%   st_combine() %>%   st_union() %>%   st_set_precision(1000) %>%   sf::st_make_valid() %>%   st_transform(st_crs(mlt_pa_data)) %>%   sf::st_make_valid()  # clip Malta's protected areas to the coastline mlt_pa_data <-   mlt_pa_data %>%   filter(MARINE == "terrestrial") %>%   st_intersection(mlt_boundary_data) %>%   rbind(mlt_pa_data %>%         filter(MARINE == "marine") %>%         st_difference(mlt_boundary_data)) %>%   rbind(mlt_pa_data %>% filter(!MARINE %in% c("terrestrial", "marine"))) ## Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout ## all geometries ## Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout ## all geometries # recalculate the area of each protected area mlt_pa_data <-   mlt_pa_data %>%   mutate(AREA_KM2 = as.numeric(st_area(.)) * 1e-6) # print first six rows of the data head(mlt_pa_data) ## Simple feature collection with 6 features and 32 fields ## Geometry type: GEOMETRY ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: 1382584 ymin: 4291797 xmax: 1399759 ymax: 4299407 ## Projected CRS: +proj=cea +lon_0=0 +lat_ts=30 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs ## # A tibble: 6 × 33 ##      WDPAID WDPA_PID  PA_DEF NAME  ORIG_NAME DESIG DESIG_ENG DESIG_TYPE IUCN_CAT ##       <dbl> <chr>     <chr>  <chr> <chr>     <chr> <chr>     <chr>      <chr>    ## 1 555588631 555588631 PA     Il-M… Il-Majji… Park… National… National   II       ## 2    174757 174757    PA     Il-Ġ… Il-Ġonna… List… List of … National   III      ## 3    174758 174758    PA     Bidn… Bidnija,… List… List of … National   III      ## 4    194415 194415    PA     Il-Ġ… Il-Ġonna… List… List of … National   III      ## 5    194417 194417    PA     Il-W… Il-Wied … List… List of … National   III      ## 6    194418 194418    PA     Il-B… Il-Ballu… List… List of … National   III      ## # ℹ 24 more variables: INT_CRIT <chr>, MARINE <chr>, REP_M_AREA <dbl>, ## #   GIS_M_AREA <dbl>, REP_AREA <dbl>, GIS_AREA <dbl>, NO_TAKE <chr>, ## #   NO_TK_AREA <dbl>, STATUS <chr>, STATUS_YR <dbl>, GOV_TYPE <chr>, ## #   OWN_TYPE <chr>, MANG_AUTH <chr>, MANG_PLAN <chr>, VERIF <chr>, ## #   METADATAID <int>, SUB_LOC <chr>, PARENT_ISO <chr>, ISO3 <chr>, ## #   SUPP_INFO <chr>, CONS_OBJ <chr>, GEOMETRY_TYPE <chr>, AREA_KM2 <dbl>, ## #   geometry <GEOMETRY [m]> # reproject data mlt_pa_data <- st_transform(mlt_pa_data, 4326) # download basemap for making the map bg <- get_stadiamap(   unname(st_bbox(mlt_pa_data)), zoom = 8,   maptype = "stamen_terrain_background", force = TRUE )  # print map ggmap(bg) + geom_sf(data = mlt_pa_data, fill = "#31A35480", inherit.aes = FALSE) + theme(axis.title = element_blank()) hist(   mlt_pa_data$STATUS_YR,   main = "Malta's protected areas",   xlab = "Year established" ) # calculate total amount of area inside protected areas (km^2) statistic <-   mlt_pa_data %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   select(-geometry) %>%   group_by(MARINE) %>%   summarize(area_km = sum(AREA_KM2)) %>%   ungroup() %>%   arrange(desc(area_km))  # print statistic print(statistic) ## # A tibble: 3 × 2 ##   MARINE      area_km ##   <chr>         <dbl> ## 1 marine       4136.  ## 2 terrestrial    84.9 ## 3 partial        13.1 # calculate percentage of land inside protected areas (km^2) statistic <-   mlt_pa_data %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   select(-geometry) %>%   group_by(IUCN_CAT) %>%   summarize(area_km = sum(AREA_KM2)) %>%   ungroup() %>%   mutate(percentage = (area_km / sum(area_km)) * 100) %>%   arrange(desc(area_km))  # print statistic print(statistic) ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   IUCN_CAT      area_km percentage ##   <chr>           <dbl>      <dbl> ## 1 IV           4195.      99.1     ## 2 V              22.2      0.525   ## 3 Not Reported   14.6      0.344   ## 4 II              2.43     0.0573  ## 5 III             0.191    0.00451 ## 6 Ia              0.145    0.00343 ggmap(bg) + geom_sf(aes(fill = IUCN_CAT), data = mlt_pa_data, inherit.aes = FALSE) + theme(axis.title = element_blank(), legend.position = "bottom")

title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas
text: wdpar R package can used clean large datasets assuming sufficient computational resources time available. Indeed, can clean data spanning large countries, multiple countries, even full global dataset. processing full global dataset, recommended use computer system least 32 GB RAM available allow least one full day data cleaning procedures complete. also recommended avoid using computer system tasks data cleaning procedures completed, computationally intensive. Additionally, processing large datasets – especially global dataset – strongly recommended disable procedure erasing overlapping areas. built-procedure erasing overlaps time consuming processing many protected areas, information protected area can output (e.g. IUCN category, year established). Instead, cleaning large datasets, recommended run data cleaning procedures procedure erasing overlapping areas disabled (.e. erase_overlaps = FALSE). data cleaning procedures completed, protected area data can manually dissolved remove overlapping areas (e.g. using wdpa_dissolve()). example procedures, please see .
code: # download protected area data for multiple of countries ## (i.e. Portugal, Spain, France) raw_pa_data <-   c("PRT", "ESP", "FRA") %>%   lapply(wdpa_fetch, wait = TRUE,          download_dir = rappdirs::user_data_dir("wdpar")) %>%   bind_rows() # clean protected area data (with procedure for erasing overlaps disabled) full_pa_data <- wdpa_clean(raw_pa_data, erase_overlaps = FALSE)  # at this stage, the data could be filtered based on extra criteria (if needed) ## for example, we could subset the data to only include protected areas ## classified as IUCN category Ia or Ib sub_pa_data <-   full_pa_data %>%   filter(IUCN_CAT %in% c("Ia", "Ib"))  # dissolve all geometries together (removing spatial overlaps) pa_data <- wdpa_dissolve(sub_pa_data)  # preview data print(pa_data) ## Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 1 field ## Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON ## Dimension:     XY ## Bounding box:  xmin: -3274101 ymin: 3403947 xmax: 879505 ymax: 5609364 ## Projected CRS: +proj=cea +lon_0=0 +lat_ts=30 +x_0=0 +y_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs ## Precision:     1500  ##   id                       geometry ## 1  1 MULTIPOLYGON (((-1747945 34... # calculate total area print(st_area(pa_data)) ## 8040807030 [m^2]

code: wdpa_clean(   x,   crs = paste("+proj=cea +lon_0=0 +lat_ts=30 +x_0=0",     "+y_0=0 +datum=WGS84 +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defs"),   exclude_unesco = TRUE,   retain_status = c("Designated", "Inscribed", "Established"),   snap_tolerance = 1,   simplify_tolerance = 0,   geometry_precision = 1500,   erase_overlaps = TRUE,   verbose = interactive() )

title: Clean data — wdpa_clean
text: x sf::sf() object containing protected area data. crs character integer object representing coordinate reference system. Defaults World Behrmann (ESRI:54017). exclude_unesco logical UNESCO Biosphere Reserves excluded? Defaults TRUE. retain_status character vector containing statuses protected areas retained cleaning process. Available statuses include: "Proposed", "Inscribed", "Adopted", "Designated", "Established". Additionally, NULL argument can specified ensure protected areas excluded according status. default argument character vector containing "Designated", "Inscribed", "Established". default argument ensures protected areas currently implemented excluded. snap_tolerance numeric tolerance snapping geometry grid resolving invalid geometries. Defaults 1 meter. simplify_tolerance numeric simplification tolerance. Defaults 0 meters. geometry_precision numeric level precision processing spatial data (used sf::st_set_precision()). default argument 1500 (higher values indicate higher precision). level precision generally suitable analyses national-scale. analyses finer-scale resolutions, please consider using greater value (e.g. 10000). erase_overlaps logical overlapping boundaries erased? useful making comparisons individual protected areas understanding "effective" geographic coverage. hand, processing step may needed (e.g. protected area boundaries going rasterized), processing time can substantially skipping step setting argument FALSE. Defaults TRUE. verbose logical progress data cleaning reported? Defaults TRUE interactive session, otherwise FALSE.

title: Clean data — wdpa_clean
text: sf::sf() object.

title: Clean data — wdpa_clean
text: function cleans data following best practices (Butchart et al. 2015; Protected Planet 2021; Runge et al. 2015). obtain accurate protected area coverage statistics country, please note need manually clip cleaned data countries' coastline Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Exclude protected areas according status (.e. "STATUS" field). Specifically, protected areas status specified argument retain_status excluded. default, protected areas "Designated", "Inscribed", "Established" status retained. means default behavior exclude protected currently implemented. Exclude United Nations Educational, Scientific Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Biosphere Reserves (Coetzer et al. 2014). step performed argument exclude_unesco TRUE. Standardize column names. important data imported shapefile file geodatabase format column names. Specifically, present, "PARENT_ISO3" field renamed "PARENT_ISO" "SHAPE" field renamed "geometry". Create field ("GEOMETRY_TYPE") indicating areas represented point localities ("POINT") polygons ("POLYGON"). Exclude areas represented point localities reported spatial extent (.e. missing data field Geometries wrapped dateline (using sf::st_wrap_dateline() options "WRAPDATELINE=YES" "DATELINEOFFSET=180"). Reproject data coordinate system specified argument crs (using sf::st_transform()). Repair invalid geometries manifested (using st_repair_geometry()). Buffer areas represented point localities circular areas using reported spatial extent (using data field "REP_AREA" sf::st_buffer(); see Visconti et al. 2013). Snap geometries grid fix remaining geometry issues (using argument snap_tolerance lwgeom::st_snap_to_grid()). Repair invalid geometries manifested (using st_repair_geometry()). Simplify protected area geometries reduce computational burden (using argument simplify_tolerance sf::st_simplify()). Repair invalid geometries manifested (using st_repair_geometry()). "MARINE" field converted integer codes descriptive names (.e. 0 = "terrestrial", 1 = "partial", 2 = "marine"). "PA_DEF" field converted integer codes descriptive names (.e. 0 = "OECM", 1 = "PA"). Zeros "STATUS_YR" field replaced missing values (.e. NA_real_ values). Zeros "NO_TK_AREA" field replaced NA values areas data reported applicable (.e. areas values "Applicable" "Reported" "NO_TK_AREA" field). Overlapping geometries erased protected area data (discussed Deguignet et al. 2017). Geometries erased areas associated effective management categories ("IUCN_CAT") historical precedence retained (using sf::st_difference()). Slivers removed (geometries areas less 0.1 square meters). size areas calculated square kilometers stored field "AREA_KM2". Trimming extra leading trailing white space characters "MANG_PLAN" field  (e.g., " ", "\n", "\r").

title: Clean data — wdpa_clean
text: function can used clean large datasets assuming sufficient computational resources time available. Indeed, can clean data spanning large countries, multiple countries, even full global dataset. processing full global dataset, recommended use computer system least 32 GB RAM available allow least one full day data cleaning procedures complete. also recommended avoid using computer system tasks data cleaning procedures completed, computationally intensive. Additionally, processing large datasets -- especially global dataset -- strongly recommended disable procedure erasing overlapping areas. built-procedure erasing overlaps time consuming processing many protected areas, information protected area can output (e.g. IUCN category, year established). Instead, cleaning large datasets, recommended run data cleaning procedures procedure erasing overlapping areas disabled (.e. erase_overlaps = FALSE). data cleaning procedures completed, protected area data can manually dissolved remove overlapping areas (e.g. using wdpa_dissolve()). example processing large protected area dataset, please see vignette.

code: wdpa_fetch(   x,   wait = FALSE,   download_dir = tempdir(),   force_download = FALSE,   check_version = TRUE,   n = NULL,   page_wait = 2,   datatype = "gdb",   verbose = interactive() )

title: Fetch data — wdpa_fetch
text: x character country download data. argument can name country (e.g. "Liechtenstein") ISO-3 code country (e.g. "LIE"). argument can also set "global" download protected areas available database (approximately 1.1 GB). wait logical data immediately available download session paused ready download? argument wait FALSE data ready NA returned. Defaults FALSE. download_dir character folder path download data. Defaults temporary directory. avoid downloading dataset multiple times, recommended use persistent directory (e.g. rappdirs::user_data_dir("wdpar"); see Examples ). force_download logical data previously downloaded available argument download_dir, fresh copy downloaded? Defaults FALSE. check_version logical data imported argument download_dir, data checked see version number matches latest version available online? Defaults TRUE. n integer number records import per data source. Defaults NULL data imported. page_wait numeric number seconds wait web pages load finding download URL Protected Planet. Defaults 2. Since process finding download URL requires navigating multiple web pages, default argument means function take least 8 seconds complete. Users slow internet connections may experience issues default argument (e.g. resulting error containing message Error: Summary: NoSuchElement). avoid , users can try specifying greater value (e.g. 5 seconds). datatype character denoting file format download protected area data. Available options include: ("shp") shapefile format ("gdb") file geodatabase format. Defaults `"gdb". Note global data available file geodatabase format. verbose logical progress downloading data reported? Defaults TRUE interactive session, otherwise FALSE.

code: # \dontrun{ # obtain url for New Zealand data nzl_url <- wdpa_url("New Zealand", wait = TRUE) print(nzl_url) #> [1] "https://d1gam3xoknrgr2.cloudfront.net/current/WDPA_WDOECM_Oct2024_Public_NZL.zip"  # obtain url for New Zealand data using its ISO3 code nzl_url <- wdpa_url("NZL", wait = TRUE) #> Error in self$check_active(): Chromote has been closed. print(nzl_url) #> [1] "https://d1gam3xoknrgr2.cloudfront.net/current/WDPA_WDOECM_Oct2024_Public_NZL.zip"  # obtain url for global data global_url <- wdpa_url("global") print(global_url) #> [1] "http://wcmc.io/wdpa_current_release" # }

what: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas — wdpar
title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas — wdpar
text: wdpar R package provides interface data provided Protected Planet. Specifically, can used automatically obtain data World Database Protected Areas (WDPA) World Database Effective Area-Based Conservation Measures (WDOECM). also provides methods cleaning data databases following best practices (outlined Butchart et al. 2015; Protected Planet 2021; Runge et al. 2015). main functions wdpa_fetch() downloading data wdpa_clean() cleaning data. information, please see package vignette. cite package, please see citation("wdpar").

title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas — wdpar
text: Butchart SH, Clarke M, Smith RJ, Sykes RE, Scharlemann JP, Harfoot M, ... & Brooks TM (2015) Shortfalls solutions meeting national global conservation area targets. Conservation Letters, 8: 329--337. Protected Planet (2021) Calculating protected OECM area coverage. Available : https://www.protectedplanet.net/en/resources/calculating-protected-area-coverage. Runge CA, Watson JEM, Butchart HM, Hanson JO, Possingham HP & Fuller RA (2015) Protected areas global conservation migratory birds. Science, 350: 1255--1258.

title: wdpar: Interface to the World Database on Protected Areas — wdpar
